docs.lead_paragraph: Sitting two seats from Laura Bush in the House gallery tonight was one of the more unusual guests ever invited by a White House to a State of the Union speech: an acknowledged former crack addict and prostitute who now runs a drug treatment program in a Louisiana Christian church. The guest, Tonja Myles, director of the Set Free Indeed program at the Healing Place Church in Baton Rouge, La., was called by White House aides last week after they found a newspaper article about her work, church officials said.

headline.main: Guests Put a Human Face On the President's Ideas
headline.kicker: STATE OF THE UNION: THE AUDIENCE

docs.snippet: Sitting two seats from Laura Bush in the House gallery tonight was one of the more unusual guests ever invited by a White House to a State of the Union speech: an acknowledged former crack addict and prostitute who now runs a drug treatment program...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush vowed tonight that he would not burden future generations with the nation's pressing domestic problems: growing budget deficits, a lagging economy and a crisis in health care. He offered few new specifics on how he would solve those problems, and Democrats asserted that some of his proposals could actually worsen them. But Mr. Bush, addressing one of the core critiques of his administration, argued that he ''will not pass along our problems to other Congresses, other presidents and other generations.''

headline.main: President Vows Steps to Handle Domestic Woes
headline.kicker: STATE OF THE UNION: DOMESTIC AGENDA

docs.snippet: President Bush vowed tonight that he would not burden future generations with the nation's pressing domestic problems: growing budget deficits, a lagging economy and a crisis in health care.    He offered few new specifics on how he would solve those...

byline.original: By ROBIN TONER and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg outlined his latest plan yesterday to balance the city budget, this time shifting the focus away from city actions and placing his trust largely in Albany and the city's labor unions to help close a $3.4 billion gap. The plan, announced at City Hall, avoided draconian cuts and widespread layoffs. But even as the mayor was wrapping up his budget address about noon, some city officials and budget experts cautioned that it could be short-lived. They said some crucial elements of the mayor's plan might have to be reconsidered as soon as today, when Gov. George E. Pataki is set to outline his plan to cut the state budget by billions of dollars.

headline.main: Mayor's Budget Plan Relies on Help From Albany and Labor

docs.abstract: Mayor Michael R Bloomberg outlines his latest plan to balance New York City budget, this time shifting focus away from city actions and placing his trust in Albany and city's labor unions to help close $3.4 billion gap; Bloomberg is looking to Albany for roughly $1.7 billion in budget relief; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of President Bush's State of the Union address, as recorded by The New York Times: Every year, by law and by custom, we meet here to consider the state of the union. This year, we gather in this chamber deeply aware of decisive days that lie ahead.

headline.main: President's State of the Union Message to Congress and the Nation
